It is my great pleasure to inform you that our article entitled "Extended State-Dependent Differential Riccati Equation (ESDDRE) Controller Design for a Chemical Plug-Flow Reactor via Time-Delay Partial Differential Equation" has been published in "Iranian Journal of Science and Technology, Transactions of Electrical Engineering". This paper offers a nonlinear controller for a non-isothermal PFR governed by time-delay first-order partial differential equation (PDE). Due to, an Extended state-dependent differential Riccati equation (ESDDRE) of the PFR system, a sub-optimal nonlinear controller is suggested. At the first step, an Extended pseudo-linearization (EPL) presentation of the PFR with State-dependent coefficients (SDC) is designed. All of the time-delay terms in this representation are situated in the input vectors as well as the system matrices. Then, a control signal regard on the ESDDRE controller is generated by introducing a Hamiltonian equation and performance index according to the PDE systems. Moreover, the asymptotic stability regarded on ESDDRE controller is guaranteed by applying a suitable Lyapunov theory. Simulation results verify the efficiency of the recommended ESDDRE controller method for two EPL form presentations with different time delays. #optimalcontrol #SDRE #PDE #Riccati

In the realm of chemical engineering and thermodynamics, understanding the behavior of gases, especially under varying conditions of temperature and pressure, is fundamental. The concept of non-ideality in the vapor phase plays a crucial role in this context, diverging from the simplistic assumptions of ideal gas behavior to embrace the complexities of real-world phenomena. Ideal gas laws, while providing a foundational understanding, often fall short in accurately predicting the behavior of gases under high pressure or low temperature conditions, where molecular interactions cannot be ignored. Non-ideality in the vapor phase acknowledges these interactions, incorporating factors such as volume exclusion and intermolecular forces, which become increasingly significant in dense gases or when the system pressure exceeds a certain threshold. This blog post explains how the volume of vapor decreases when pressure increases, especially when the system's pressure goes above 5 atmospheres because the molecules interact more. For calculations involving the balance between vapor and liquid phases (vapor-liquid equilibrium, or VLE), it's important to consider that both the vapor and liquid phases may not behave ideally. An equation of state can help with calculations for fractionating columns, which separate components based on differences in boiling points. The ideal equation for VLE states that the total pressure multiplied by the vapor phase mole fraction equals the vapor pressure multiplied by the liquid phase mole fraction. However, to account for non-ideal behavior, two additional parameters are introduced: Gamma (γ) for the liquid phase non-ideality and Phi (Φ) for the vapor phase non-ideality. The modified equation becomes P * Y * Φ = VP * X * γ , indicating how these parameters are used to account for the non-ideal behavior in both phases. The exploration of non-ideality in vapor and liquid phases underscores the complexity of real-world chemical processes and the limitations of ideal models. By integrating the non-ideal behavior of both phases into VLE calculations, engineers and scientists can achieve more precise and reliable predictions, essential for the efficient design and optimization of separation processes. The addition of Gamma and Phi parameters to the VLE equation represents a pivotal step towards embracing the intricacies of phase behavior, ensuring that theoretical models more closely mirror actual conditions. This knowledge not only enriches our understanding of thermodynamic principles but also enhances the practical capabilities of chemical engineering applications. #chemicalengineering #thermodynamics #VaporPhase #IdealGasLaw #STEM #innovation #techtalk #futuretech #sustainability #Scienceeveryday #engineeringlife #industrialengineering

Understanding Heat Transfer: Conduction, Convection, and Applications Heat transfer is a fundamental concept in various fields, including engineering, physics, and chemistry. It plays a crucial role in designing and optimizing systems, devices, and processes. In this post, we'll delve into the basics of heat transfer, conduction, convection, and their applications. 📝What is Heat Transfer? Heat transfer is the transfer of thermal energy from one body or system to another due to a temperature difference. It occurs through three primary methods: conduction, convection, and radiation. 📝Applications of Heat Transfer: Heat transfer has numerous applications in various fields, including: ✒️Chemical Engineering: Heat transfer is crucial in chemical reactions, distillation, and separation processes. ✒️Power Generation: Heat transfer is used in power plants to convert thermal energy into electrical energy. ✒️Refrigeration and Air Conditioning: Heat transfer is used to transfer heat from one location to another, providing cooling or heating. ✒️Materials Science: Heat transfer is used to study the thermal properties of materials and their applications. ✒️Aerospace Engineering: Heat transfer is used to design and optimize heat shields, thermal protection systems, and propulsion systems. 📝Heat transfer is a fundamental concept that plays a vital role in various fields. Understanding conduction, convection, and radiation is essential to design and optimize systems, devices, and processes. By applying the principles of heat transfer, we can improve efficiency, reduce costs, and develop innovative solutions. Share your experiences and applications of heat transfer in the comments below! A Review of #Top-#Submerged #Lance (#TSL) Processing—Part I: Plant and Reactor Engineering! New review paper at the MDPI journal #Metals! Within this #review, we have aimed to highlight #major #features of #TSL #processing, such as feed flexibility and high conversion rates due to the induced turbulence, low dust generation, and low fugitive emissions. In addition, the reactor is analyzed part by part, also taking into account patent literature, focusing on #furnace #design, #settling #furnaces, #feeding #systems regarding input material streams such as concentrates and fuels, #vessel #cooling #arrangements, #off-#gas #system, and aspects associated with the #refractory #lining. Furthermore, specific focus is given to the centerpiece of the #TSL #reactor,i.e., the #reactor #lance. Associated developments are examined, which have focused on establishing a #slag #coating to hinder lance wear, the use of #fluid-#cooled #lance and #shroud #air arrangements, the increment of #O2 #enrichment in air, and on influencing of #fluid #dynamics (e.g., O2 conversion at the lance tip, bubble formation, and bath splashing). #TSL #reactor #applications and #developments are summarized within dedicated tables thus allowing a presentation of the status that the technology has reached today within the industry! In addition, I would like to thank #AUSMELT and #ISASMELT colleagues for their valuable inputs during the preparation of this review! Hope you enjoy the read!

Experimental investigation on heat transfer in a gas-solid fluidized bed with a bundle of heat exchanging tubes https://lnkd.in/debt72MR Abstract A fluidized bed reactor is commonly used for highly exothermic reactions for different chemical industrial processes. However, inefficient removal of the generated heat due to the exothermic reaction can seriously influence reactor performance. Hence, quantifying and understanding the heat transfer phenomena in this reactor is essential to enhance the performance of the reactor and consequently the chemical process. To achieve a better quantification and understanding of the heat transport in this reactor, an advanced heat transfer technique has been used in this study to quantify the impact of the presence of the cooling tubes on the local heat transfer coefficient under different operating conditions for this reactor. It has been found that the local heat transfer coefficient in the fluidized bed reactor equipped with a bundle of vertical tubes increases significantly as superficial gas velocity increases at the wall region, while different behavior was noticed at the center of the reactor. Moreover, the results show that the local heat transfer significantly decreases at the reactor's core region for all studied superficial gas velocities. Furthermore, the new tube arrangement offers a uniform local heat transfer profile for all studied operating conditions. The obtained new high-quality experimental data for the local heat transfer coefficient in a fluidized bed reactor equipped with a bundle of tubes can be used for validation CFD simulations or mathematical models, facilitating the design, scale up, and operation of this reactor. Highlights: • An experimental investigation was carried out in mimicked Fischer-Tropsch fluidized bed reactor with vertical heat exchanging tubes. • An advanced heat transfer technique was used to quantify the heat transfer coefficient locally and instantaneously. • The impact of vertical heat exchanging tubes on the local heat transfer coefficient was investigated. • The findings of this study would further improve the knowledge of the impact of vertical heat exchanging tubes on heat transfer in gas-solid fluidized bed reactor. Keywords: • Fluidized bed reactor, • Vertical heat exchanging tubes, • Local heat transfer coefficient, • Advanced heat transfer technique, • Silica sand particle Journal: https://lnkd.in/dgnvtdte Issue: https://lnkd.in/dpwEj7pq Article: https://lnkd.in/dxqpwGdk ETJ LinkedIn: https://lnkd.in/d_8SPqAt #Engineering_and_Technology_Journal #UOT #engineering #technology #etj

I am pleased to announce that our newest paper entitled: "Continuous multiphase Bunsen reactor of iodine-sulfur thermochemical water splitting cycles for hydrogen production: Experimental, Modelling and Design Insights" has been published in Chemical Engineering Journal and is now available online. This research is the result of the successuful collaboration between Università Campus Bio-Medico di Roma and ENEA Casaccia. I extend my sincere gratitude to the co-authors, who played a crucial role in this significant achievement: the Enea researchers Giampaolo Caputo, Salvatore Sau and Alberto Giaconia, for their crucial contributions to the experimental work on the innovative Bunsen reactor, my colleague Leone Mazzeo, for always being a patient and capable guide, and my supervisor Vincenzo Piemonte, for his important role of coordination. The study presents an experimental multiphase Bunsen reactor employing a new approach for liquid products concentration and its complete model, which includes novel approaches for reaction kinetics and liquid-liquid equilibrium description. Optimal conditions for the design of Bunsen-type continuous reactors are identified through a dimensionless analysis. Highlights: • A lab-scale counter-current flow Bunsen reactor was constructed and tested. • A new description of the Bunsen reaction kinetics was proposed. • Gas-liquid–liquid reactor modelling was developed with innovative approaches. • Dimensionless analysis identified optimal conditions for reactor design.
